lead_paragraph: Seven executives joined the board of the Advertising Club of New York. They are: Dawn Bullen, senior vice president for media at Macy’s; Marnie Kain Cocossa, executive vice president and global equity director at Saatchi & Saatchi, part of the Publicis Groupe; Colleen De Courcy, chief digital officer, TBWA Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group; Rachel Goldflam, marketing manager for Burberry, who is the young professional president for the club; Todd Harvey, director for North American advertising, Citigroup; Mari Kim Novak, director for United States marketing at the advertising division of Microsoft; and Robin Steinberg, senior vice president and director for print, MediaVest USA, part of the Starcom MediaVest Group division of Publicis.

abstract: Google is being upfront about its self interest in building public pressure for a plan to allow soon-to-be-vacant broadcast spectrum for new high-speed wireless Internet access. The airwaves, known as “white spaces,” will be unused after TV stations switch to all digital broadcasts next February, and the Federal Communications Commission is expected to decide their fate soon.
snippet: Google is being upfront about its self interest in building public pressure for a plan to allow soon-to-be-vacant broadcast spectrum for new high-speed wireless Internet access. The airwaves, known as “white spaces,” will be unused after TV statio...
lead_paragraph: Google and other technology giants like Microsoft, Intel and Dell, have long pushed for a plan to allow soon-to-be-vacant broadcast spectrum to be used to provide new high-speed wireless Internet access networks. The airwaves, known as “white spaces,” will be unused after TV stations switch to all digital broadcasts next February, and the Federal Communications Commission is expected to decide their fate soon.

headline.main: Google Starts an Advocacy Campaign for More Unlicensed Spectrum
